comment.narrative: 1.1 .UNDP has provided support to the Ministry of Social Development (MSD) in preparing the National Action Plan on Gender Equality 2015-2017 according the National Strategy for Gender Equality (2012-2020). 1.2.UNDP has supported the Ministry of Internal Affairs in development the National Action Plan on UN SC Resolution #1325 1.3.UNDP contributed to building capacity of national partners on implementation of international and national gender equality commitments: MSD Gender Policy Department Head and Board Member of Association of Women Police Officers participated in Regional Conference on Effective Programming for Enhancing Women’s Security and Access to Justice, Including Preventing and Combating Sexual Gender- Based Violence. 2. Gender equality objectives have been reflected in UNDP programme AWPs. UNDP Kyrgyzstan has increased the resources allocated for gender mainstreaming activities (about 20% from overall budget), including two projects marked by Gender Marker 3. 3. 95% of staff completed the online gender mainstreaming courses. Country Office Gender Focal Point and Country Programme Gender Coordinator’s capacities strengthened through participating at ITC-ILO Gender Academy and by participating UNDP Regional Conference on Effective Programming for Enhancing Women’s Security and Access to Justice, Including Preventing and Combating Sexual Gender- Based Violence. 4. Successfully partnered with UN Women, UNODC, OSCE on substantive joint project initiatives – support to the National Women's Forum of the Kyrgyz Republic, initiated by International Public Foundation “Initiative of Roza Otunbayeva”; UN Women, NDI, IRI, OSCE – support to the International Conference “Parliament Role in Advancing Gender Equality in context of Bejing+20”; ACTED - EXTENDED CONSULTATIVE MEETING of interagency working group members on the development of National action plan on implementation of UN SCR № 1325 for 2015-2017 with the civil society representatives; UN Women, Fried

Activity Results 1: 1.1.UNDP has provided support in implementing the National Action Plan on Gender Equality (2015-2017) – the part related to output 3.1.2.1. “To generalize the judicial practice on crimes against women and girls during the period of 2011-2014 (articles 129, 130, 132, 133, 144, 153, 154, 155 of the Criminal Code) and to make recommendations for the proper and uniform application of the rules by the courts. Develop a document on training of judges of all district, inter-district and regional courts based on recommendations for correct and uniform application by the courts of law on crimes against women and girls”. 1.2. Support provided on implementation the National Action Plan on UN SC Resolution #1325. Gender experts developed methodology and training programme on UNSCR 1325 “Women, Peace and Security” in order to build capacities for law enforcement agencies of KR in September 2016. The training itself was facilitated to representatives of Military Institute of Law Enforcement, as well as resource materials for curriculum introduced. The resource book for Law Enforcement agencies was disseminated 1.3. UNDP contributed to building capacity of national partners on implementation of international and national gender equality commitments: the Head of Gender Policy Department of the Ministry of labour and social development was supported for participation the International forum «Reconsidering Gender Equality and Peaceful Societies» (Bangkok, May 7-8, 2016); MP Altybaeva for participation in 60th session of CSW in NY; 1.4. Several Gender and Leadership schools for women MPs and women-candidates were conducted; 1.5. Technical support in advocating for several draft laws initiated by women MPs were provided, one on registration of early religious marriages is signed by the President, the domestic violence law is due for the second hearings, gender quotas in local elections is due for the second hearings). 1.6. comment.narrative:
Output 1: 1. Availability of the priority Government activities within Public Administration Reform, including optimization of public and municipal service system, LSG development and E-Governance, and strengthened national legislative framework.
Output 2: 1. Capacities of the President and Prime-minister Offices, and selected governmental institutions to develop and implement a country policy and Public Administration reform are weak, as well as their internal operations are inefficient.

Output 1. Professionalism, efficiency, transparency and accountability of public administration improved through policy support and capacity development Target1. At least 3 drafts of bylaws within implementation of the Law “On Provision of Public and Municipal Services” developed and submitted to the Prime-minister Office.
Output 2. Internal operations of identified state institutions improved leading to strengthened policy development and implementation Target 2. Updated analysis on promotion of foreign policy with respective recommendations submitted to the President Office.

Output 1. Result: 3 drafts Government Decrees developed for the effective and timely implementation of the Law “On Provision of Public and Municipal Services”. These legal acts (the Law and Government Decrees) are a key step in area of improving of public administration reform, where questions of public services are being essential and primarily for society. These normative legal acts directly concerns the entire population, and aims to ensure the quality and accessibility of services for the citizen.
Output 2. Result: Updated analysis on promotion of foreign policy in the regional and cross-border cooperation of the KR in Central Asia with respective recommendations was developed and submitted to the President Office in view of increasing the efficiency and capacity of Foreign Policy Department of the President’s Office.

Output 1: 1. # of conflict prevention-related laws/ strategies/ plans/ policies drafted, amended, passed or implemented (# of which promote gender equality). 2.1.# of stakeholders trained and capable to apply MPR-D methodology. 2.2. # of scenario cases developed and discussed. 3. # of dialogue platforms conducted and # of preventivemeasures/ actions taken following these platforms (# of measures that promote gender equality issues and increasing the role of women in peacebuilding). 4. # of mediation and dialogue pilots implemented and documented.
Output 2: 1. # of local NGOs, advisory committees, women and youth organizations able to monitor and respond to potential conflict escalation (# of women leaders in the trainings and # of preventive actions undertaken by women. 2. # of capacity building interventions conducted for Advisory Committees that have led to concrete positive changes in their work (# of interventions with tangible benefit for the role of women in peacebuilding). 3. # of new collaborations/ initiatives kick-started in the area of conflict monitoring and preventive action based on networking efforts. 4. # of documented cases in which ICT for conflict prevention was used in the context of monitoring and preventive action. 5. # of women initiatives contributing to confidence- and peacebuilding.
Output 3: 1. # of recommendations of risk assessment accepted by border security and considered for future planning. 2. # of consultations/ negotiations supported towards reaching agreement on possible cross-border cooperation between Kyrgyzstan and Uzbekistan.

comment.narrative:
Output 1: 1. National Institutions have limited capacities to design and implement conflict prevention policies. Governmental officials were not aware on conflict sensitivity, gender aspects, and had no enough skills to develop policy. 2. Government doesn’t use methodology to manage political risks for development. 3. Prior to International Conference on conflict sensitive law-making there was no dialogue between civil society and authorities. There is lack of collaboration between Oblast-level officials and civil society on one side and state decisions makers on the other to jointly monitor tensions and take early preventive action (including mediation). 4. Lack of support to mentor and coach real mediation processes or mediation practice support.
Output 2: 1. Local NGOs, advisory committees, women and youth organizations have limited ability to monitor and respond to potential conflict escalation. 2. Advisory Committees have limited capacities to initiate conflict prevention and peace building interventions. 3. Local NGOs, advisory committees, women and youth organizations do not sufficiently coordinate their efforts. 4. ICT review has identified lack of support for ICT development in peace building. 5.Lack of support to women driven initiatives in peace building.
Output 3: 1. Limited capacities to assess potential conflict risks related to border security. 2. Lack of cross border cooperation between Kyrgyzstan and Uzbekistan.

Target #1. At least 3 recommendations from the assessment were taken up and implemented by development partners, civil society and/or national stakeholders Target #2. Dialogues carried out and collaborations facilitated have been covered at least 8 times by the media Target #3. At least 5 incidents were tracked and responded to (documentation of cases with reflection on their outcomes) Target #4. At least 3 conflict sensitive activities of youth/women empowerment action plans supported

Electoral Risk Management Tool (ERM) offered free-of-charge by IDEA (Sweden) to National Institute for Strategic Studies (NISS) has been adjusted and launched after baseline electoral risk assessment. 10 weekly reports on possible electoral risks have been prepared and discussed during inter-agency coordination workshops engaging law enforcement structures, Central Electoral Committee and relevant Government bodies including security services and Defense Council. Local authorities jointly with community leaders from both sides of the border addressed 3 critical issues (based on incident reports produced by local monitors) related to re-construction of local market (adding additional trading spaces for Tajik residents), moving mobile border post on the strategic road Ovchu Kalacha-Beshkent, which posed difficulties for internal movement of Kyrgyz residents and advanced negotiations between local authorities on joint re-habilitation of the shared road. Moreover monitoring reports laid the ground for negotiations of other 12 projects aimed at improving cross border relations. Most of projects related to rehabilitation or construction of water infrastructure and required extensive consultations between different government and non-government bodies due to sensitivity of the cases (located on disputed territories where border demarcation and delimitation has not finalized yet). UNDP supported 16 day campaign to prevent violence against women and girls with active involvement of local media resources, supported Karakol Mayor’s office to launch participatory process of drafting youth empowerment action plan, assisted Kok-Oy LSG to reduce conflict potential with involvement of youth through youth empowerment activities.

5 % increase in number of cases relating to conflicts that LSGs targeted in the project have addressed with support of the Agency for LSG Affairs and Interethnic Relations and their affiliated structures
Key national institutions able to design and implement conflict prevention policies, and manage risks to stability

comment.narrative: 1. 2000 people (40% are women) improved skills on business and agriculture development 2. At least 300 beneficiaries (with special focus on women and youth) received access to soft loans through Revolving Fund 3. 50 SMEs, including women-lead established 4. Not less than 10 000 people (50% are women) received access to potable and irrigation water 5. 30 % of unemployed people have an access to new workplaces due to the mechanisms improved and conditions created for market-driven specialties 6. Not less than 200 jobs (for men and women) created 7. Not less than 20 000 people (40% are women) received access to improved rural infrastructure 8. 120 household income increased by 30% 9. 1. 315 beneficiaries (29% or 92 are women) improved their business and entrepreneurial skills, as well as skills in agriculture development. 32 teachers and masters (42% or 13 are women) of target vocational schools upgraded their professional skills on specialized courses. 2. 253 beneficiaries (55% or 139 are women) received microloans from the Revolving Fund for initiating and developing their income-generating activities 3. 52 small enterprises in the area of service provision, as well as production and processing of agricultural products are established 4. 11 thousand people (52% or 5720 are women) benefit from improved access to potable water. Irrigation of 5907 hectares of arable lands owned by 3068 households is improved 5. 392 people are trained on such majors as Cook, Needlewoman, and Gas and electric welder. 201 graduates (51%) are employed 6. 211 new jobs are created. 78 or 37% of jobs are created for women 7. 35275 people (9000 households, 17903 or 51% are women) benefit from access to improved infrastructure in their villages (electricity supply, village roads, street lights and others) 8. Members of 380 households from 12 pilot villages increased their income by 50% 9. 180 rural women improved their knowledge and skills in developing business in the area of dairy production, pastry production, and greenhouse farming 10. Based on improved skills and knowledge through support of the project, 12 new veterinary service points provide high quality services, take systematic preventive measures and provide treatment to livestock. 144 members of self-help groups from 6 pilot villages increased their household income through support of the project in development of sheep breeding and provision of forage

1. No less 50 partners and beneficiaries increased capacity, improved skills on partnership, business and agriculture development 2. 1. Capacity of 307 beneficiaries and partners of the project is improved in the area of agriculture development, entrepreneurship, processing of agricultural products, management, and strategic planning. 2. 8 demonstration projects on renewable energy and alternative energy sources, such as solar collectors, biogas units, energy effective LED lightings, and solar greenhouses, are introduced. Beneficiaries developed their skills on applying new energy effective technologies. 3. 250 unemployed people received trainings on market-driven trainings. 130 graduates (52%) of the trainings found jobs 1. 3 target enterprises are provided with equipment on products processing and packaging, such as cheese production for Atbashi-Sut company (125K USD), meat processing for LLC Janar&Bek (58171 USD), and beekeeping equipment for PU Naryn Uiuk (79150 USD). 2. 160 household income increased by 30-40% through crafting and beekeeping 3. 343 women improved their business knowledge and skills 4. Livestock in 14 target villages received adequate vet services and adequate winter nutrition, which enhanced production.

independent political entity

comment.narrative: 1.Recognized and formalized mechanism of cooperation of stakeholders on RoL for implementation issues; 2.At least 20 officials and consultative body members trained on international standards and RoL matters 3. Training program and methodology on capacity building of key RoL institutions as part of the judicial reform implementation is developed 4.Methodology on financial assessments of Judicial Laws finalized 5.Built national capacity for donor coordination 6.At least ten CSOs are engaged in the Judicial reform process and their capacity is enhanced 7.Establishment of mechanism for civil society engagement in Rule of Law implementation reform process.

1.On 29 June 2015, Kyrgyz Prime Minister has signed a Decree on the creation of the Coordination Council and of the Secretariat to oversee the development of implementation plans by the working groups. The Council is chaired by the Kyrgyz Vice Prime Minister. 2.42 legal department representatives of 20 state institutions and Secretariat of Coordination Council (16 women and 26 men) participated in Rule of Law and Human Rights School aimed at awareness raising on international standards, Rule of Law, mandatory expertise, communication and cooperation. 3.Draft methodology and 12 training modules developed on new legislation for key RoL institutions. . 4.Methodology on financial assessment of judicial laws finalized, presented to the expert society. 40 representatives of the Ministry of Finance trained on the Methodology. 5.Coordination Council established under the Prime Minister’s Office is responsible for development of implementation plans and their final financial assessment. Upon finalization of implementation plans, the Coordination Council will present the final cost of judicial reform to donor society and coordinate financial contributions. To be completed in 2016. 6.4 CSOs engaged in the Coordination Council. To be completed in 2016. 7.To be completed in 2016. In cooperation with contracted CSO “Institute for Public Analysis” the Network for monitoring of judicial reform and better engagement of at least 10 civil society representatives will be established.

- Recognized and formalized mechanism of cooperation of stakeholders on RoL for implementation issues; - Training program and methodology on capacity building of key RoL institutions as part of the judicial reform implementation is developed - Methodology on financial assessments of Judicial Laws finalized - Built national capacity for donor coordination - At least ten CSOs are engaged in the Judicial reform process and their capacity is enhanced - Establishment of mechanism for civil society engagement in Rule of Law implementation reform process. - Establishment of a working group for the development of a concept plan on long term judicial reform

- The mechanisms for cooperation was established with support of donor community. The coordination council and its Secretariat is functioning and meeting on constant basis. - At least 2 training programms have been developed in cooperation with Government Office - The methodology on financial assessment is finalized and handed over to legal department of Government Office - National capacity to coordinate activities of the development partners is build via communication platforms - At least 20 CSOs are engaged and successfully monitoring the rule of law reform - The adequate mechanism to coordinate the CSO network is established by UNDP - The working group supported via national expert on development of strategic documents

- Recognized and formalized mechanism of cooperation of stakeholders on RoL for implementation issues; - Level of knowledge by consultative body members and relevant state officials on international principles and standards on cooperation in rule of Law matters increased. - Training program and methodology on capacity building of key RoL institutions as part of the judicial reform implementation is developed - At least ten CSOs are engaged in the Judicial reform process and their capacity is enhanced - Establishment of mechanism for civil society engagement in Rule of Law implementation reform process. - Establishment of a working group for the development of a concept plan on long term judicial reform

- The mechanisms for cooperation was established with support of donor community. The coordination council and its Secretariat is functioning and meeting on constant basis. - At least 5 summer schools and training meetings took place to increase the level of knowledge of consultative bodies and relevant state officials. - At least 4 training programms have been developed in cooperation with Government Office - At least 24 CSOs are engaged and successfully monitoring the rule of law reform - The adequate mechanism to coordinate the CSO network is established by UNDP - The working group supported via national expert on development of strategic documents

description.narrative: Improving the coverage and management effectiveness of Protected Areas in the Central Tian Shan Mountains.
independent political entity
Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness
To improve the coverage and effectiveness of protected areas in the Central Tian Shan Mountains so as to expand threatened species representation in the national system
Population size of snow leopard Uncia Uncia in Central Tian Shan shows an increasing trend

comment.narrative: Low numbers of snow leopard unable to quantify
By project end target area offers permanent habitat for 5 females with cubs

During field surveys conducted by the Biology and Soil Institute three sites in the Project area had signs of snow leopard activities A questionnaire among local herders indicated that about 57 snow leopards were seen in the area The snow leopard and its prey species habitat migration routes seasons directions were developed
According to the Global Snow Leopard and Ecosystem Protection Programme that aims to identify and secure 20 landscapes across snow leopard range by year 2020 there are 23 national scale landscapes Report of the FFICMS workshop Bishkek Kyrgyzstan 1st 2nd December 2014
The Project site has been included as one of the key landscapes for show leopard conservation in the Kyrgyz Republic

description.narrative: Territorial coverage of SPNAs in Central Tian Shan Mountains which provide habitat for the endangered snow leopard

comment.narrative: 1491179 ha Existing Sarychat Ertash reserve area
Up to 3361199 ha by project end

Researchers from Biology and Soil Institute of the National Academy of Sciences of the Kyrgyz Republic have conducted the field study in the Project site
Based on the results of the literature review and obtained data from field survey Biology and Soil Institute provided the following i Information on preliminary assessment of the flora vertebrates mammals birds coldblooded animals ii summary lists of flora and fauna locations biota large mammals migration routes iii Preliminary assessment of sacred natural sites and cultural landscapes of the Project site Soil types ivRecommendations for new establishing KhanTengri State Nature Park zoning and ecological corridors borders
Flora
10 vegetation types 457 plant species found and identified Out of which 5 species included in the Red Data Book of the Kyrgyz Republic 8 endemic species which are natural to or characteristic to this place 11 species can be found only in the Project site in the Kyrgyz Republic In addition 4 mosses 122 mushrooms 287 lichen were found
Fauna
100 bird species out of which 8 species included in the Red Data Book of the Kyrgyz Republic 4 species included in the Red List of the IUCN 13 species are listed in the CITES appendix II
22 mammals out of which 5 species included in the Red Data Book of the Kyrgyz Republic 4 species included in the Red List of the IUCN 4 species are listed in the CITES appendix II I
Staff of the State Agency on Environment Protection and Forestry completed a feasibility study for establishing a new PA The socioeconomic impact of the new PA was identified including i socioeconomic status population growth and land use composition measures ii current use of the Project site land for agricultural and industry use and future prospect iii water and mineral resources and their longterm perspective iv modern use of forest and game species in the Project site and prospects v anthropogenic pressures and threats to landscape nature resources
Based on the results of the feasibility study and ecological assessment tentatively an area of 325785 ha for the new park was identified which has the potential to ensure conservation of mountain fragile ecosystems including flora and fauna along with sustainable development for local people residing around the Park Out of 325785 ha 2268882 ha were identified for the core zone of the Park 17808 ha ecological stabilization zone for restoration and conservation activities 83234 ha for tourism recreational zone 727655 ha zone for limited economic activities where traditional farming practices and biodiversity friendly activities are allowed A social survey was held among local people to be impacted by the park creation ie their lands will be transferred to Protected areas category The survey involved 1383 households of which 75 indicated support for the establishment of the park and 17 against its establishment

description.narrative: Habitat connectivity sustainability and effectiveness of PAs in Central Tian Shan are enhanced by regulating land use in buffer zones wildlife corridors and other intervening landscapes
Area over which territorial land use planning is fully aligned with requirements for regulated resource use stipulated in the management plans of PA buffer zones and corridors

comment.narrative: 0 ha

0 ha
Key land owners and users in the Project site were identified The new PA area would largely consist of the AkSuu rayon state land reserve 23687170 ha Otradnaya local selfgovernment body LSGB 237763 ha Teplklyuchenka LSGB 98345 ha KeregeTash LSGB 57683 ha BoryBash LSGB 20685 ha Oktyabr LSGB 17850 ha AkBulun LSGB 65326 ha Chelpek LSGB 46466 ha Karakol forestry 345015ha
Out of 325 785 ha 49399 ha are covered with forest 127443 ha occupied by pasture lands 9324 ha covered with water bodies 50 ha of roads 101646 ha of glaciers and 2054724 ha refer to the other land category rocks or stones etc
It is expected that out of 325785 ha 988968 ha of the KhanTengri Park territory will be included in its buffer zone where limited traditional economic activities for local communities are allowed
According to the legislation on land transfer of the Kyrgyz Republic the bottomup approach is used Nine key land owners LSGB agreed to the land transfer at local level At present PA establishment documents are being prepared for getting approval at regional and oblast levels
Taking into account recommendations of the National Academy of Science on establishment of ecological corridors to connect the new KhanTengri Park with the existing SarychatEertash Reserve ecological corridors for migratory mammals were mapped and land owners identified
Local governments local selfgovernment bodies and local communities have been informed about establishing ecological corridors and its regimes
The establishment of the ecological corridors will be accomplished after approval of amendments to the Law on PAs of the Kyrgyz Republic and Regulation on Ecological Corridors which is now under the consideration of the Kyrgyz Republic Parliament and then the Government
Guidelines on development of PA management Plan prepared by the Project were approved by the order of the SAEPF Director
Biodiversity conservation has been mainstreamed into the Sustainable Development Strategy of the IssykKul region for 20152017 and its Action Plan

description.narrative: Better management of hunting in buffers and corridors as reflected in percent of trophy hunting that is controlled and monitored

comment.narrative: Only 30 of trophy hunting is legal because hunters are uncontrolled and unmonitored
90 of trophy hunting is legally licensed

During the reporting period 100 of trophy hunting was controlled and monitored in the Project site
0 cases of violation by trophy hunters were recorded
A rangers handbook developed by the Project is under SAEPF approval After approval the handbook will be published and distributed to rangers and volunteer inspectors to improve their capacity in nature management

description.narrative: Increase in share of incomes of local communities from biodiversitycompatible alternative livelihood activities

comment.narrative: More than 60 of income comes from hunting
By project end at least 60 of income comes from sustainable livelihoods promoted by the project

No quantitative indicator is available at the moment
Project will be able to measure the quantitative indicator of change in share of incomes of local communities from biodiversity compatible livelihoods only in 2016
Social and economic assessment of target communities and development of Alternative Livelihood Programme has been completed

description.narrative: Law on SPNAs provides clear guidance on establishment management and responsible party for PA buffer zones and wildlife corridors

comment.narrative: Current law is unclear
Legislation improved through amendments by project end

No change of the baseline indicator
According to the Law on Protected Areas of the Kyrgyz Republic 2011 there are 4 zones in the state nature parks core zone ecological stabilization zone touristrecreational zone zone for limited economic activities
In accordance with SEAPF and Project board meeting suggestions November 2014 the above mentioned zones except for the core zone should be accepted as a buffer zone for the State Nature Park KhanTengri
During the reporting period the Project has reviewed the gaps in PA legislation and policy concerning establishment of zones its regimes and ecological corridors
The Project initiated review of the Law of the Kyrgyz Republic on PA By the Project support the following legislations were drafted The Regulation on PA establishment in the Kyrgyz Republic Regulation on Red Data Book of the Kyrgyz Republic Regulation on land use in State Nature Parks Regulation on Ecological corridors and proposal for making amendments to Law on PA submitted to SAEPF for further endorsement These documents are under consideration of the Government of the Kyrgyz Republic
In addition the Project provided technical support for development of a programme and action plans on transition to sustainable development of the ecological and economic system of IssykKul for 20152017 which was later integrated to the Sustainable Development Strategy of the IssykKul region for 20152017 and its Action Plan for the implementation of the Sustainable Development Strategy of the IssykKul region for 20152017 approved by order of the Plenipotentiary Representative of the Government of the Kyrgyz Republic in IssykKul region dated February 9 2015 21 On approval of the Strategy for Sustainable Development of the IssykKul region for the years of 2015 2017
Biodiversity has been mainstreamed into the Sustainable Development Strategy of the IssykKul region for 20152017 and its Action Plan for respective years

description.narrative: Prosecution of illegal hunting in buffers and corridors

comment.narrative: Only 10 of incidents of illegal hunting successfully prosecuted
At least 50 of incidents of illegal hunting successfully prosecuted from Year 4 onwards

According to the Biosphere Territory IssykKul and volunteered inspectors the following data on prosecution of illegal hunting in the Project area have been obtained
i the first half of 2014 JanuaryJune 24 violations were registered out of which 17 illegal hunting 7 illegal logging of total collected penalty of 2500 USD
ii the first half of 2015 JanuaryJune 51 violations were registered of which 21 illegal hunting 15 illegal logging and 15 other cases of total penalty collected of 14255 USD
iii the second half of the 2014 JulyDecember 14 violations were registered of which 7 illegal hunting 5 illegal logging and 2 other cases of total penalty collected of 3399 USD
During the first half of 2015 51 violations were detected for a total amount 14255 USD first half of 2014 24 violations were detected for a total amount 2500 USD
Thus the detecting rate has been increased from 24 to 51 and the penalties amount from 2500 USD to 14255USD compared to the previous period
In total during this reporting period the second half of the 2014 and the first half of 2015 65 violations cases of the nature conservation legislations were recorded out of 28 cases on illegal hunting 20 cases on illegal logging and 17 other cases for carrying hunting weapons etc for the total penalty amount of 17654 USD
The Project enhanced the capacity of the Biosphere Territory IssykKel Karakol Nature State Park of SAEPF rangers and freelance inspectors through trainings workshops on involving local communities for awareness raising biodiversity conservation activities and conducting wildlife monitoring
The Project purchased and provided a group of volunteer inspectors with uniforms and equipment tent portable radio set GPS navigator binoculars etc for monitoring and conservation of wildlife and supported the antipoaching activities of Biosphere Territory IssykKel rangers
Department on Nature Resources Regulation passed the order in August 2014 to temporarily ban until 2016 game and sport hunting of all ungulate species in several regions of Kyrgyzstan including all districts of the IssykKul region

description.narrative: Reduced hunting effort directly attributable to changes in livelihoods among hunters

comment.narrative: 500 persons hunting in the area
150 reduced by 13 persons hunting by project end

No progress is reported at the moment in line with projects workplan
Development of the Alternative Livelihood Programme has been completed and the Programme implementation will cover local communities and people
It is expected that the Project will be able to evaluate or assess the changes in livelihoods of local communities in 2016

Justice, Law and Order - policy, planning and administration

1. Number of Universal Periodic Review (UPR) recommendations relevant to the project implemented; 2. Free Legal Aid framework in line with international standards; 3. Rate of formal and informal justice institutions representatives' average knowledge in the area of law (in pilot project regions) 4. Rate on accessibility to formal justice institutions by project target groups' representatives ; Increase in the rate of accessibility to informal justice institutions by the project target groups' representatives (in pilot project regions) 5. % of women, youth (boys and girls) and PwDs (men and women) rating quality of FLA as fully satisfactory (in pilot project regions) 6. % of women, youth (boys and girls) and PwDs (men and women) who are aware of their rights and duties (in pilot project regions) 7. % of the project target groups representatives who have passports, birth and marriage certificates (in pilot project regions)

comment.narrative: 1. 11 out of 36 relevant to the project Universal Pediodic Review recommendations implemented by Kyrgyzstan: general recommendations - 7 out of 9; women's rights - 2 out of 12; children's rights - 2 out of 7; People with Disabilities (PwD) - 0 out of 8 2. Free Legal Aid framework (FLA) focused only on criminal cases and do not comply with international standards 3. Formal justice institutions representatives in pilot project regions rated their average knowledge in the area of law as 3,82 out of 5; informal justice institutions representatives in pilot project regions rated their average knowledge in the area of law as 3,39 out of 4. 4. Project target groups representatives in pilot project regions rated accessibility to formal justice institutions as 2,77 out of 5; Project target groups representatives in pilot project regions rated accessibility to informal justice institutions as 2,54 out of 5 5. 17,8% of women; 14,4% of youth and 25,6% of PwDs in pilot project regions rated quality of FLA as fully satisfactory 6. 41,62% of women, 36,50% of youth and 62,82 % of PwDs are aware of their rights and duties (in pilot project regions) 7. 92,22% of the project target groups representatives have passports, 97,58% have birth certificates and 46,73% have marriage certificates (in pilot project regions)

1. 12 out of 36 Universal Periodic Review recommendations relevant to the project implemented; 2. Draft FLA law includes access to FLA for the victims of crimes that is in line with international standards; 3. 3 % increase in the rate of formal and informal justice institutions representatives' average knowledge in the area of law (in pilot project regions); 4. 3 % increase in the rate of accessibility to formal justice institutions by the project target groups' representatives; 10% increase in the rate of accessibility to informal justice institutions by the project target groups' representatives (in pilot project regions) 5. 3 % increase in % of women, youth (boys and girls) and PwDs (men and women) rating quality of FLA as fully satisfactory (in pilot project regions) 6. 3 % increase in % of women, youth (boys and girls) and PwDs (men and women) who are aware of their rights and duties (in pilot project regions) 7. 1.7 % increase in % of project target groups representatives, who have passports, birth and marriage certificates (in pilot project regions)

1. 7 UPR recommendations relevant to the project implemented: in particular, 5.31; 5.32; 5.59; 5.100; 7.3; 7.5; 7.6. 2. Draft law on Free Legal Aid includes access to FLA for the victims of crimes and civil cases (effective as of the year 2017). The draft law is submitted to the Parliament and adopted in the 1st reading on 26 June 2015. 3. Analysis of training modules on the rights of vulnerable groups is completed with recommendations for the development of the new module for formal and informal justice institutions and state bodies. Training module is to be developed and trainings provided in the year 2016. 4. Project supported opening of the Ministry of Justice 5 FLA centers (3 in Chui and 2 in Osh provinces). For the last 9 months 13 636 legal consultations were provided by these centers. 4 court buildings (1 in Bishkek city, 1 in Osh city and 2 in Kara-Suu and Nookat districts of Osh province) were made accessible: ramps were constructed, entrances to the meeting halls and reception area were widened. 24 sign-language interpreters were trained on legal issues to provide support to the deaf mutes. 5. Legal clinic has provided 93 consultations and assisted in preparation of 30 legal documents. Central database of the Ministry of Justice is transferred to Open Data format and available in the mobile application.
6.4 centers on legal empowerment were opened in pilot provinces (2 in Chui and 2 in Osh). Database of people in need of legal aid was compiled by the local lawyers and 521 consultations provided during the 4 months period. 243 people received free legal aid by the lawyer of the Ministry of Justice in team of the State Registration Service’s (SRS) mobile group.
7. State Registry System mobile groups issued documents to 150 persons in the project’s pilot Ayil Aymaks starting from September 2015. 10 automated informational systems with protected channel for documentation of the population were installed in pilot provinces. Business processes for 7 serv

1. 6 UPR recommendations relevant to the project implemented; 2. Draft law on Free Legal Aid in line with international standards adopted by the Parliament; 3. 3 % increase in the rate of formal and informal justice institutions rep-resentatives' average knowledge in the area of law (in pilot project regions); 4. 3 % increase in the rate of accessibility to formal justice institutions by the project target groups' representatives; 3% increase in the rate of accessibility to informal justice institutions by the project target groups' representatives (in pilot project re-gions) 5. 3 % increase in % of women, youth (boys and girls) and PwDs (men and women) rating quality of FLA as fully satisfactory (in pilot project regions) 6. 3 % increase in % of women, youth (boys and girls) and PwDs (men and women) who are aware of their rights and duties (in pilot project regions) 7. 1.7 % increase in % of project target groups representatives, who have passports, birth and marriage certificates (in pilot project regions)
